Fails to meet Airbnb occupancy standards

An enterprising New Yorker sought to turn a walloping snowfall into a money spinner by building an igloo in his backyard and advertising it as a boutique getaway for two on Airbnb for $200 a night.

But freelance art director Patrick Horton said his icy listing lasted on the property-sharing website just six hours before he was informed that it was being removed for not meeting occupancy standards.

Mr. Horton said he and two roommates spent six hours building Brooklyn’s answer to a traditional Arctic home.

He then advertised the ‘Boutique Winter Igloo for 2’ on Airbnb in hip neighbourhood Greenpoint.

Despite Airbnb giving him the cold shoulder, Mr. Horton says he got five enquiries while the listing was live.

“Interestingly enough, Airbnb actually allows igloos to be rented,” he said. “There are igloos on their site, but for some reason ours did not meet the qualifications.”

Airbnb did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Mr. Horton says he is thinking about advertising it on Craigslist, despite a second day of warmer temperatures that has seen some of New York’s enormous snowfall melt. — AFP
title: Boutique igloo for two in N.Y. fails to make the cut
